b"b' Implement a new GC handle profiler.'"

b'b" This profiler was initially developed for Moonlight to diagnose andfix issues where objects were never being GC\'ed due to gchandlesbeing attached to objects and not freed. This profiler is just asuseful for other frameworks which rely on GCHandles to provide memorymanagement facilities such as gtk-sharp. The aim of this profiler is to allow you to easily see how many instancesof each class are being kept alive by GCHandles and also the stacktracefrom where the GCHandle was allocated. The profiler also tracks when instance delegates are passed  nativecode as this can be a severe performance hit if it is done frequently."'
b"b' Question: could we link the object files for mono-mutex.c into the profiler module? That way it would have its own internal copy of the mutex. That being said
column11: my main feedback is: where are the docs for this? ;-) Remember the Mono Team Mantra: if the feature is not documented
column12: it does not exist.'"

column11: UTIME_NOW and UTIME_OMIT might not be available on all systems (I think they are in POSIX.1-2008). If the constants are not available the get_at_fdcwd() method will not be compiled
column12: which will cause an EntryPointNotFoundException at runtime. If they are fields
column13: the exception will be thrown in the static ctor which will make the class unusable.'"

column10: b"b' Fixes Bug #333898 / Fixes Bug of losing  sessions (InProcSessions) when using Phalanger with Mono'"
b'b" For previous comments
column11: see: url  Ok. I identified and fixed the bug:The first request calls OnReleaseRequestState() for acquiring a exclusive lock on the Session store.Next concurrent requests trying to access the same Session store will wait in WaitForStoreUnlock()WaitForStoreUnlock() calls StoreUnlockWaitCallback() for checking if the Session store was releasedThis is done by calling SessionStateModule::GetStoreData()
column12: which changes the shared SessionStateModule::storeData variable.If the storeData is locked (it was locked by the first request)
column13: a NULL value is returned and stored in storeData.When the first request is released on OnReleaseRequestState()
column14: storeData is NULL and GetItemExclusive() is called with a item == null
column15: so the session is destroyed (as reported in bug #333898) To fix this bug
column16: I changed SessionStateModule::GetStoreData() so it doesn\'t assign a NULL value to storeData when an item is locked.SessionStateModule::GetStoreData() will now return a SessionStateStoreData object
column17: which will be assigned in StoreUnlockWaitCallback() only when not NULL: So
column18: if the store was locked (that\'s mostly the case because we are waiting it to unlock)
column19: storeData will not be changed for the executing request (which got the lock) and also will not the destroy the session during OnReleaseRequestState()."'

column10: b"b' BTW
column11: just looking at the code
column12: there seems to be another bug: In OnReleaseRequestState() the lock is released with ()
column13: and then
column14: at the end of the function
column15: storeData is assigned: If another thread gets the lock before storeData is assigned null
column16: his storeData will be destroyed and  will get lost in the same way as the bug I fixed above. Please confirm. Thanks.'"

b"b' Bring resources implementation close to .NET 2 standard.'"

b'b\' ## Implementation of StronglyTypedResourceBuilder This is an implementation of the class along with quite thorough test coverage.## Bring  closer to .NET 2 standard A limited implementation of .NET 2 ResX handling was present in mono\\\'s . .NET 2 ResX handling is based around the ResXDataNode class
column11: these can be returned from a ResXResourceReader with UseResXDataNodes set to true encapsulating the resources in the file. Where as before ResXResourceReader simply returned the instantiated resource objects
column12: this class provides details about the resource entry
column13: including comments against it in the ResX file
column14: the details of its location in the file system (through a ResXFileRef object) if it is not embedded and so on. Overloads of GetValueTypeName return the type of the resource object and GetValue returns the actual resource object
column15: both of which accept parameters to customise the type resolution. With the mono implementation
column16: the ResXDataNode simply held a copy of the instantiated resource object
column17: you couldn\\\'t tell if the resource was from a file at all. The GetValue (...) and GetValueTypeName (...) overloads simply returned this object or its type respectively and any parameters passed in were ignored. Unit tests against .NET revealed it was very inconsistent itself. The ITypeResolutionService parameter passed in to GetValue and GetValueTypeName are sometimes ignored and sometimes used to resolve types. This depends on the way the resource are stored in the ResX file and under numerous conditions the output of one does not reflect the other. To be as compatible as possible this has been replicated. Unit tests also show that a ResXDataNode created from a resource in a ResX file keeps the "serialised" string value pulled from the XML and this is used by the ResXResourceWriter when being written back again. Support for soap formatted serialisation has also been added. ResXResourceWriter has been updated to write out comments as well as support added for the BasePath property which now changes an absolute path to one relative to that specified. Code for type resolution has been moved from ResXResourceReader to ResXDataNode. Exception types have been updated to match .NET. Unit tests have been included for everything.\''

column10: b"b' Fix sigaltstack on BSD'"
b'b" Linux uses some specific behavior for sigaltstack
column11: whereas OS X and FreeBSD (and likely the other BSDs) use the default flag value of 0. This fix changes the conditional macro to check for **linux** instead of **APPLE**
column12: so that Linux can use the appropriate flag and other platforms can use the default. As this change allows sigaltstack to work correctly on BSDs
column13: I\'ve removed the explicit setting for FreeBSD so it is enabled automatically when supported by the system. It is likely that sigaltstack now works on the other BSDs
column14: but since I haven\'t had a chance to test them yet
column15: I left their settings as-is. This change has been tested (with the standard test suite
column16: via  ) on FreeBSD 9.1 (i386
column17: amd64) and Ubuntu 12.04.1 (i386)
column18: and all but 2 tests pass on both platforms."'

column10: b'b" Hi Miguel -no code was actually changed here. The original source assumes the difference in behavior between OS X and Linux is specific to OS X; it checks if the symbol is defined and if not
column11: uses the Linux-specific behavior. However
column12: the code passing the flag value is Linux-specific -other OS\'s use the default behavior. So
column13: if the behavior is not changing for Linux or OS X
column14: on which OS\'s could the behavior possibly break due to this change? According to the
column16: netbsd
column17: openbsd
column18: and android specifically disable \'sigaltstack\'
column19: leaving nacl
column20: hpux
column21: solaris
column22: and haiku. After looking at the sigaltstack documentation for [HP-UX]url  and the other OS\'s
column23: it turns out this code exposes some sloppiness in Linux\'s implementation of \'sigaltstack\'. According to the [POSIX standard for sigaltstack]url  passing any value other than or in the field should cause the function to return an error value ( ). The flag can only be passed _out_ of the function. So
column24: the conditional macros can be eliminated from the Mono code altogether here -the value should _always_ be set to zero for this call to sigaltstack
column25: even on Linux. (The [NaCl code]url  for Linux uses the default flag as well.)"'

column10: b'b" The reason for the different values of the  class is the different handling of the IsFixedDateRule property. If is is a fixed date rule the Week and DayOfWeek properties don\'t make sense and in Mono they are set to -1. If it is not a fixed date rule the Day property don\'t make sense and in Mono it is set to -1. But in .Net the properties are set to 1 or . These different values between platforms produced some headache for the implementation of the serialisation of this class."'
b"b' The general rule is to behave exactly like Microsoft .NET
column11: so if the values there are different it should be fixed in Mono (in a different PR with corresponding unit tests).'"

column10: b"b' [] Caching threads and bulk fetching StackFrames'"

b"b' :  Fixed wrong version check  Changed Thread_GetFrameInfo signature to be asynchronous Invalidating StackFrame for thread when methods are invoked because stack will probably change...A bit complicated thread safe mechanism to be able to handle InvalidateFrames in middle of fetching and not hang in any case...Reason why method InvalidateThreadsAndFramesCache is called inside Resume is because XS had caching of Threads for few years now and it was invalidating ThreadList every time Resume was called so it makes sense to invalidate here...  InvalidateThreadsCache is separated from InvalidateThreadsAndFramesCache  because in case of new threads or stopped threads there is no need to invalidate all frames...  if ( (2
column11: 34)) check before making batched fetch is to prevent any possible regression on older runtimes and do fetch 1 by 1 the old way...'"

b"b' IDisposable design pattern specify that the implementation of Dispose() and Dispose(bool) should allow for the method to be called more than once. Close should call Dispose or Dispose(bool) Testet under  This change is released under the MIT license.'"

mono	1247	closed	4	madrang	2014-08-31 03:01:59	114.83			+1	b'b\' More testing show some behavior that i wasn\\\'t expecting.All tested under  in a console application.Set SafeHandle to be the owner of the handle If the last reference is removed by a call to DangerousRelease, all calls to Dispose or Close throws ObjectDisposedException If Close or Dispose are called while there are more than one reference. (Added by using DangerousAddRef), those call do nothing. ReleaseHandle is never called, doesn\\\'t matters how many times you call them. More reference can be added with DangerousAddRef. When the last handle is released by DangerousRelease, ReleaseHandle triggers and  can still be called with no exceptions. If Close or Dispose are used to release the last reference to SafeHandle, they can be called any number of times with no exception. Only DangerousAddRef and DangerousRelease result in ObjectDisposedException. In all cases Close and Dispose shows the same behavior. After the handle is Disposed, DangerousGetHandle returns . It will remain unchanged after being released. It need to be set in the ReleaseHandle override to an invalid value and even then DangerousGetHandle returns the invalid value with no exceptions. SetHandleAsInvalid will never change the value of the handle, it only marks it as closed.DangerousRelease will still allow for the remaining reference to be released.DangerousAddRef will throw ObjectDisposedException event if refcount is ReleaseHandle is never called, (as if the SafeHandle is not the owner anymore).The finalizer will not be called, where usually the finalizer calls Dispose(false) When SafeHandle is not the owner of the handle, the same behavior happens, except that ReleaseHandle is never called and DangerousGetHandle will keep returning a "valid" but closed handle. The Finalize method is not called. The overriding class finalizer is only called if base(ownshandle:true). The  SafeHandle implementation allow for the handle to be kept alive even after Dispose is called if some other threads still have a reference to it. Disposing only happens after the last reference is released. But i dont understand why Dispose and Close would behave differently depending on how the last reference was released.... Since using DangerousRelease on the last reference will make Dispose throw an exception and that the finalizer will still be executed by the GC, using DangerousRelease on the last reference result in Unhandled Exception: : Safe handle has been closed at () at (Boolean disposing) at ConsoleApplication1(Boolean disposing) at () at ConsoleApplication1() Wow... The default  implementation throws an exception in the Finalize method...\''

column10: b"b' url  Close should call virtual Dispose(true) to allow overriding classes to close. After SetHandleAsInvalid the Finalizer will not run under  Dispose should be safe to call more than once and never throw in finalization. Right now  will only throw on Dipose in a very specific cases. An it will also happen in the GC Thread... We should not try to copy this behavior.(If last call to DangerousRelease caused the resource to be released
column11: the next call to Close or Dipose under  will throw. Even if called by the GC in a finalizer.) Unhandled Exception: : Safe handle has been closedat ()at (Boolean disposing)at ConsoleApplication1(Boolean disposing)at ()at ConsoleApplication1()'"

column10: b"b' [Runtime] Added optional canaries to mempool allocation.'"
b'b" I find it a little odd that it could cause a regression because it\'s all inside of an ifdef that isn\'t defined. "'
b"b' build'"

b'b" This patch doesn\'t follow much of the style we use in the runtime. Which is to delimit features using functions and using stubs if they are not enabled. We got to reduce the number of ifdefs inside functions
column11: not increase. With this in mind
column12: I suggest the following changes: -Let size accounting include canaries when they are enabled
column13: it\'s actually a feature to know real sizes as this would make it easy to measure the memory overhead of different canary sizes. -Always add PADDING (and rename it to something more explicit) and make it zero when canaries are disabled. -Change the recording ifdef blob to be a function call which will be an empty function when canaries are disabled. -Never use assert but the g_ variants. Avoid g_assert in favor of g_error as it will give you context.We have  integration on top of the g_ functions which is important for embedders. -You\'re missing the fast path case in mono_mempool_alloc0. -The canary must start at the unaligned address and not at the rounded up one. This is very important as it helps catching off-by-one errors on those structs that are ignored because of rounding."'

column10: b'b\' I hate to use the "works on my machine" line
column11: but the  test works on my machine. Also I fail to see how adding mempool canaries that are disabled in these tests could trigger it. \''

column10: b'b" There\'s a bunch of small changes needed
column11: but this patch otherwise."'

column10: b'b\' This change introduces "overlapping" indexes for locals debug info in mo...\''
b'b\' This change introduces "overlapping" indexes for locals debug info in mono for the runtime. The debug info format and the soft debugger have logic already that makes this work
column11: the only thing missing was to make mono return the index of locals with debug info instead of just of just one item by index. This change should be  compatible (ie older  debugger and same for runtime). What this fixes:Code like Where "a" and "b" reuse the same local variable slot. Before this change "a" will show as a debug entry when it\\\'s in that scope. And in the scope for "b" nothing is shown at all. After this change both show as they should. This change is released under the MIT license.\''

b"b' [RFC] Add timeout feature for test suite'"
b"b' If TEST_TIMEOUT is set to a value (e.g. 300s)
column11: the test suite will be aborted when a timeout occurs. Right now
column12: the System testsuite hangs on Linux / Jenkins. Since this testsuite runs pretty early on
column13: we get very limited test results as Jenkins aborts the whole job after a while. With this feature we could set TEST_TIMEOUT on Jenkins to an appropriate value and get results from  the other testsuites as only the problematic one would be aborted. RFC: what do you think?'"

column10: b"b' cc @directhex'"
b"b' @marek-safar what do you think?'"
b"b' Why does Jenkins abort the job? If some tests hungs we need to fix the test as it can happen for everyone'"
b'b" I think jenkins aborts the job as it doesn\'t have steps."'
b'b\' Yes
column11: Jenkins just runs "make check" from the root dir so it has no visibility into the individual steps.We could certainly change that to cd and run make check in each directory (I think this is what Wrench does?)
column12: but keeping the list updated when things change seems brittle. Regarding the hang
column13: @alexanderkyte already looks into that afaik.\''

column10: b"b' Is there any log of the hang?'"
b'b" @marek-safar see url  for some comments
column11: but it repros 100% here so I can gather additional output if you want. As I said it hangs on Jenkins consistently as well
column12: so this seems like it\'s not my machine alone."'

column10: b'b" It\'s not really clear to me which test is  from that log"'
b'b" @marek-safar It\'s not a single test that hangs
column11: it only seems to occur when the entire System testsuite is executed. It then seems to hang at this specific test (see also a recent [Jenkins log]url  (running that test alone works)."'

column10: b'b\' I think "register that something timed out but carry on"
column11: which is what this PR allows
column12: is a MUCH better pattern than "the build is stuck
column13: abort & mark it failed"
column14: which is how Jenkins currently behaves.\''

mono	2864	closed	3	migueldeicaza	2016-04-10 14:30:47	7.23		+1		b"b' This breaks when the system python is 2.x, which is the case on MacOS, a major platform for us. So this patch is of no use in its current form.'

column10: b"b' @migueldeicaza wait
column11: why would it break on 2.x? As far as I know
column12: all Python implementations understand as a function
column13: while only 2.x versions understand it as a statement in addition.'"

column10: b'b" @migueldeicaza I don\'t see why this should break 2.x compatibility? The way I wrote it makes it compatible to both python2 and python3. I tested it with Python 2.7.11 on Linux and it happily accepted it. Python 2.x treats the argument to the print statement as expression and and evaluate to the same output. Python 3.x treats print as function and thus requires the parentheses. The only difference is when using in a print (cf. url  which does not happen here."'
b"b' I verified this still works on Python 2.7 on OSX 10.11 so this is fine and a good change
column11: thanks!'"

column10: b'b" Btw. just for reference: this shouldn\'t impact the build in any case since acceptance-tests is not required for the build."'
b"b' [sgen] Speed up domain finalization at shutdown'"
b'b" When we cleanup the gc at shutdown
column11: we no longer care about running the remaining finalizers so we set the suspend_finalizers flag. This flag skipped running the finalizers but we would still traverse and modify the sgen finalizer hashes (on an arm box this could take even longer than 1s and lead to finalizer_thread_exited assertion failure since it\'s over the 100ms limit). Avoid traversing sgen finalization hashes as soon as we see that we are shutting down."'

column10: b"b' Is there a reason do to that in the outer loop? Why not moving it into the inner loop?'"

b'b" We already check for suspend_finalizers inside mono_gc_run_finalize and inner loop is very small (64) so functionality wise it would be the same. It\'s therefore just a matter of taste and it just looked nicer to me like this."'
b"b' I see.  LGTM then.'"
b'b" This is a breaking change. Can\'t be done like this."'
b'b" More specifically:breaking changes must be ok\'d by tech leadershipit must be justified and take into consideration all our scenarios.  For example
column11: do we want to force this behavior on everyone? Should it be toggleable? same behavior for desktop and embedders?such a change must be first discussed and documented on the related release notes"'

column10: b"b' @kumpera Why is this a breaking change ? It has no impact on  many finalizers are run. Once we are shutting down we already set suspend_finalizers which means that we are no longer running any finalizers (we check for this flag in mono_gc_run_finalize). So basically right now
column11: when suspend_finalizers is set
column12: we just repeatedly iterate and update a potentially big hash of finalizable objects
column13: just not to run any finalizers anyway. This change only exists the loop earlier.'"

column10: b'b" WTF
column11: you\'re right. If we\'re not running the finalizers at all
column12: how on earth can it take that much time?!?!"'

column10: b'b" Well
column11: on one extreme stress test where the assertion happened we had hundreds of thousands of objects to be finalized. And for each one of these objects we are doing a free-ing operation (for the hash entry)
column12: which I suspect takes the most time. Since at the moment we don\'t free the gc memory at shutdown
column13: we might as well not do this potentially expensive step."'

column10: b"b' LGTM
column11: can it be merged?'"

column10: b'b" @schani Want also to take a quick look ? Also
column11: do you know why we\'re not using open addressing for the finalization hashes. Right now we\'re doing an  for each entry which seems pretty slow on finalization intensive scenarios. I would like to take care of that in the future."'

column10: b"b' Looks good.  should be
column11: btw. The hash table is probably historic and nobody has looked at it in a long time.'"

column10: b'b" [DONTMERGE]  Martin\'s TLS Playground ([appletls]: Disable implicit keychain lookup on Desktop Mono.)"'
b'b\' Reading the private key from the keychain is a new feature introduced with AppleTls on XamMac and iOS.  This patch only affects Desktop Mono on the Mac
column11: where this new feature has some known issues and not received any testing yet.  We go back to the old way of doing things
column12: which is to explicitly provide an with a private key.   When using  or
column13: we try to search the keychain for the certificate and private key.  On
column14: this is easy because each app has its own keychain.  On
column15: the package needs to be trusted via code-sign to get permission to access the user\\\'s keychain.  [FIXME: I still have to research how to actually do that.]  Without this
column16: you will get a popup message each time
column17: asking you whether you want to allow the app to access the keychain
column18: but you can make these go away by selecting "Trust always".  On Desktop Mono
column19: this is problematic because selecting "Trust always" give the \\\'mono\\\' binary (and thus everything you\\\'ll ever run with Mono) permission to retrieve the private key from the keychain.  The following code would also trigger constant keychain popup messages
column20: which could only be suppressed by granting full trust.  Since you do not need to use the keychain for AppleTls
column21: we currently disabled it on Desktop Mono until we have a better understanding of how these mechanisms work to provide a smooth solution.\''

column10: b"b' Unfortunately
column11: this does not work.  See url '"

column10: b"b' Reopening this PR to research how to disable the keychain popups.'"
b"b' Fix InternalsVisibleTo being case-sensitive & fix internal access checks not applying to constructors'"
b"b' Presently on Windows the Microsoft CLR ignores case when checking InternalsVisibleTo attributes against the currently executing assembly. Roslyn matches this behavior. On the other hand
column11: mono and mcs both treat this attribute as case-sensitive.  This PR changes mcs & the mono runtime to use case insensitive comparisons when matching the attributes so that behavior matches the MS CLR.  This PR also fixes a bug in the JIT where internal access checks were not being performed for constructor invocations (NEWOBJ)
column12: only method invocations.  PR still  quality so happy to revise based on feedback.'"

column10: b"b' We could get some improvement by splitting the locks among sre types or images. '"

b'b" @kumpera Doesn\'t look sgen is made to account for the presence of the tombstone in the root. I\'d assume there are no crashes because the hashtable is used only in the MONO_HASH_VALUE_GC mode."'

b'b" @vargaz for the workload in question splitting between sre and non-sre would have zero impact are there\'s virtually no SRE going on.  Splitting the locks means splitting the hashtable as well. Doing it per-image is complicated due to appdomains.  We could have a single hash per image and hash on method
column11: class and domain. The issue with that is during unload we\'d have to scrub all images to remove all reflection entries. Not particularly something I look forward doing.  This patch solves the reflection perf issue
column12: which the per-image locking has no guarantee of doing at all.  "'

column10: b"b' @BrzVlad we use a marker object as tombstone when the hashtable has object keys.  '"
b"b' Another approach
column11: complicated as well
column12: is to move these hashes to managed code.'"

column10: b"b' @vargaz how moving them to managed would help us here?  '"
b"b' Thats what .net does i think.'"
b'b" I looked at dotnet
column11: what they have are short lived (using weakrefs) per-type caches for all sorts of reflection queries. It\'s a lot of code that I\'m not 100% sure on importing.  All that caching should help
column12: but we\'d still need to have the refobjects hash as you can\'t have multiple instances of MethodInfo around for the same method AFAICT. "'

column10: b'b" The OSX failures are completely unrelated.  The previous run didn\'t show them up and the only change after than was merging win32 build support."'

column10: b"b'   Fix some ThreadPool performance counters.'"

b'b" Fix some ThreadPool performance counters. url The bug is that some performance counters are always zero. Because we do not update them. This addresses two of them: Work items added and thread count.  There is an argument to just leave it not working or remove the non-working counters
column11: granted.  There is PerformanceCounter class and you can Increment instances
column12: however its metadata and some of the implementation is in . Most of the code is in native. ThreadPool is in
column13: so can\'t use . A few options exist to address this. We could move and forward the type. We could duplicate and rename and possibly subset the type. Here we add a new icall very specifically for the scenario.  There is slight cost for the icall
column14: and for the atomic increment. Doing this using the existing managed way would have the same atomic increment. Using any new managed would have similar motivation.  There is an attempt to measure but the results were unclear.  Note that the count of work items is not specifically for QueueUserWorkItem as one might expect
column15: but also for any async calls.  Fix a little bit of typos."'

b'b\' I have noticed that in []url  fork() is #if\\\'d out with the message "_DO NOT directly call fork(2); it bypasses essential shutdown code. Use  instead_".  What happens specifically? starts a process
column11: it does not shut anything down? should just work
column12: does it not (effectively (copy on write)) copy the entire VM which then each shuts down independently? does work in Python on Unix (multiprocessing module).   is powerful
column13: it supports using processes as an alternative to threads. One can not test for a one in a million race condition. only replaces then  . I wish to use to support replicated processes
column14: starting with a complete copy of the application\\\'s state greatly simplifies this.\''

pass unicode from C# through to underlying layer w/o any conversion back and forth" -it should work that way and no change to alter that.\''
mono	6465	closed	2	alexrp	2018-01-09 19:40:45	360.17		+1		b'b" How about we keep the current and simply modify the Windows implementation to use to look up the thread handle and then do what is currently done in your  ?  It does mean an extra encoding conversion and having to do a thread ID Maybe there\'s some other solution here that I\'m not seeing. I just don\'t like having two separate APIs that essentially do the same thing but have different names depending on platform. We should abstract that away."'
mono	6465	closed	3	jaykrell	2018-01-09 19:40:45	157.33		+1		b'b\' I thought I had gotten the other user.  There is a certain part of this that I don\\\'t like. It is "ok" for Mono to have set_thread_name_ascii and set_thread_name_unicode, but really, unlike what I show here, they should both try to spread the name around to all known other interested parties. Nobody should call set_thread_name_ascii and set_thread_name_unicode in sequence -what I have is not great. Roughly speaking, each should call the other. Or rather, each should call an underlying implementation that will do its best to convert each to each, and pass them on to whoever is interested.  So, let me present that.  As well, what do you think about passing id and handle, and using whatever we have?  In particular, really, handle is the right thing for Windows. Just that Visual Studio did its wierd thing many years earlier.  So, like ascii and unicode, or utf8 and utf16 if you will, how about the underlying api take threadid and threadhandle, using threadhandle if present, else threadid.  Like this:  void mono_set_native_thread_name_new_version ( ThreadId threadId, void* threadHandle, const gchar* utf8, gsize utf8_length, const mono_unichar* utf16, gsize utf16_length, )  if windows  if mscver  if we have utf16 but not utf8, convert if we have threadhandle but not threadid, convert  pass threadid and utf8 to RaiseException  endif mscver  if we can get SetThreadDescription pointer:  if we have utf8 but not utf16, convert  if we have threadid but not threadhandle, convert  pass threadhandle and utf16 to SetThreadDescription endif SetThreadDescription  endif windows  existing monoapi mono_set_thread_name_native(id, utf8):  mono_set_native_thread_name_new_version(id, null, utf8, strlen(utf8), null, 0) existing callers mono_set_thread_native_native: call mono_set_native_thread_name_new_version with whatever we have Let me code that up tonight more completely. \''
mono	6465	closed	4	luhenry	2018-01-09 19:40:45	274.93		+1		b'b" Let\'s keep the existing and call from there, and even on top of that, what does this adds on top of the existing solution?"'
mono	6465	closed	5	jaykrell	2018-01-09 19:40:45	344.1		+1		b'b" I\'m working on fixing it so caller just makes one call, potentially what they already call i.e. If they have no utf16. Char is a smaller boolean. SetThreadDescription has several  detailed in the comments. The other API is to the debugger & maybe not all of them. This is to the operating system, newer ones."'
mono	6465	closed	6	jaykrell	2018-01-09 19:40:45	1271.9		+1		b'b" Let\'s do this after coop of set name, but let\'s be sure that coop of set name does not lose the utf16 flowing from managed."'

b'b" The goal is
column11: in combination with #6611
column12: to make the definition of private and to access all fields via getter methods.  This PR moves the field definitions for MonoClass out to a separate file and uses it to automatically define getters of the form  ### Collected feedback  1. The use of macros for field definition and getter declarations makes the code less discoverable.   We don\'t expect new fields to be added frequently enough that the macros are helping us.   Also the longer-term goal for the getters is to add checked build assertions to them to ensure   that a field is accessed only after the has been initialized sufficiently to setup that   field.  So getters for various fields would still need to be tweaked individually.  My response: I basically agree with this.  I still want some helper macros for the getter bodies
column13: I think
column14: but having a readable definition
column15: and a readable list of getter declarations is pretty important. 2. One cute trick we could do is to make a vtable of getter functions so field accesses could look like:  .  Longer term we could dispatch different classes to different getter implementations.  My response: the cute pun doesn\'t look so cute anymore once we allow dynamic dispatch might as well be wrapped in a call.  Plus I\'m really not sold on the near-term need for dynamic dispatch.  3. Make it so that in non-checked builds the definition is visible and all the getters are  .  In checked builds
column16: hide the definition everywhere except the initialization code and the getter implementations.   My response: \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8d 4. The boolean flag getters should have names like or rather than or
column17: respectively.   Response: okay
column18: done.  ### TODO  [x] ~Hang the definition hiding on a separate define.  Just is too broad and breaks
column19: for example
column20: the coop jenkins job (which is configured with  )~"'

b'b\' MonoGCHandleType is public
column11: rarely used
column12: slightly out of date. GCHandleType is authoritative
column13: correct
column14: heavily used.  However
column15: we don\\\'t want to ship additional files
column16: and we don\\\'t want to expose a name without "Mono" prefix
column17: and profiler should not maybe include any more
column18: so now MonoGCHandleType is authoritative and correct
column19: and GCHandleType aliases it.  Just keeping them in sync is fragile and would  require casting in C++. Much better to actually  have one type
column20: with perhaps multiple names.  Spell out enum values for easier to read headers. Maintenance is slighty more difficult but a good trade off for reading. Avoid duplicate values in enum type so debugger has only once choice to show.\''

column10: b"b' The alternative is to duplicate the exact text but with an ifndef dedicated to not duplicating it
column11: and a comment to keep them in sync. That will work and serve the immediate goal but is less elegant. Like a header include guard but for a few lines. This is an existing pattern in C runtime headers but not often needed. Usually text lives in only one file.'"

b'b" I don\'t think and should be the same at all.  They serve different purposes.  In fact we probably ought to have 3:  1.  : this is the type used by the interface between SGen and SGen clients (it is valuable
column11: IMO
column12: to maintain the fiction that there are non-Mono SGen users in the world. It requires us to maintain a simple interface to a complex piece of code). 2. (missing type): this is the type used internally by the runtime to represent the various kinds of global handles that it may have access to.  This is a subset of that\'s actually used by the runtime and managed. 3.  : this is the type of handles that may be created by the embedding API. It\'s a subset of (2) (or at least convertible to (1) if we decide to stop supporting one of the handle sorts in the runtime itself
column13: we still need to maintain enough compatibility so the API stays usable).  It\'s perfectly reasonable
column14: for example
column15: that it\'s missing the Weak Fields handle type that may be something that we don\'t want API users to create arbitrarily.  A separate question is: how do we ensure that the conversion from to is simple (ie
column16: ideally just a cast).  One way would be to add a test  that asserts that the known enum values are the same.  (The downside is that this is one more place to update if we add a new handle type)."'

column10: b'b\' Chinese characters cause "String conversion error: Illegal byte sequence encounted in the input."\''
b'b\' Hi I\\\'m running a dot net application under windows with mono. I have created library in C program to load my dot net application
column11: but i found a bug in **g_utf8_to_utf16**  my program is placed in a path with a Chinese character
column12: mono can not load assembly
column13: and all Chinese characters in path become messy codes. It causes the program can\\\'t work correctly. After referenced the source code
column14: I found that this is the result of the error of the **g_utf8_to_utf16** function
column15: it converts English characters but does not convert Chinese characters
column16: eg \\xe2\\x80\\x98\\xe6\\xb1\\x89\\xe2\\x80\\x99. it will throw _"String conversion error: Illegal byte sequence encounted in the input"_.This made me quite upset
column17: because my program will run on the Chinese version of the Windows
column18: I really do not know how to do. I think mono should support Wide char(**wchar_t**)
column19: That will make it easier for people in more countries to use.\''

column10: b"b' Could you help us to reproduce the issue with the sample we can use?'"
b"b' **This is my C program:**   **After debugging
column11: I found where the problem was : mono_file_map_open**  Is there any other solution to this problem? Or are some of the parameters not set right? '"

column10: b"b' @jaykrell are you familiar with this code?'"
b'b\' Call stack would be nice.  Windows 8 bit strings are generally not utf8
column11: but are being treated here as so. That is likely the problem.  The right fix is that mono should use unichar2 or wchar_t (more) extensively and avoid converting to 8 bits
column12: except at the Posix boundary. This is how Windows works and is not unreasonable for all software. wchar_t is widely supported
column13: not just on Windows. It doubles or quadruples some memory use
column14: but that is already largely happening anyway. We and much other software already traffic extensively in wchar or unichar2 on all platforms.  1 The obnoxious non-fix is to tell user to call MultiByteToWideChar(CP_ACP) and then WideCharToMultiByte(CP_UTF8) on all 8 bit input before passing it to mono. He has done something likely invalid but only subtley so.  2 A practical and friendly fix is wherever monoapi has mono_foo(const char* presumed_utf8) also  provide mono_foo_w(const wchar_t*)
column15: implemented by converting to utf8 and calling mono_foo. (Very long term
column16: the layering  be reversed
column17: but that is probably never.)  "w" is for "wide" -for any given string-taking function CreateFile
column18: Windows actually has CreateFIleW that takes wchar_t and CreateFileA that takes an 8bit string
column19: in code page that can vary per user and per thread but is rarely UTF8 (only recently did Windows allow UTF8  as the implicit codepage). While this ugly to be sure
column20: it is a widely used existing practise and does work. So follow that on a small scale. To start
column21: one function
column22: mono_domain_assembly_open_w.  The user\\\'s code would remain invalid and not working
column23: but easy to fix. He would change char to wchar_t and A to W
column25: and append "_w" at the mono boundary.  3 Another gross fix
column26: and risky because it might not work
column27: is to try to pass the string through unmodified
column28: to fopen instead _wfopen. This is risky because it depends on carefully never assuming the encoding of user input
column29: and assuming whatever we pass it to agrees (it would in this case). And we\\\'d have to discern user input from our own utf8 data. If our data is always 7-bit clean
column30: then it is viable.  I suggest 2. It is small. It can be done incrementally but will never be huge -a bunch of one liners. It doesn\\\'t contradict 1 or 3
column31: but is more practical than 1 and more helpful than 3.\''

column10: b"b' You could also try to open the path as CP_UTF8 or CP_ACP in some order
column11: see what works
column12: but probing behavior is really not great. There is hypothetically data that is valid in each encoding but with different meaning and when you probe you make it kinda non deterministic. CP_ACP is really to be avoided
column13: despite it being widespread.'"

column10: b"b' @lewurm is this known ?'"
b'b" The issue is a missing null check in the implementation. This code causes a crash:  while this doesn\'t:  In the latter case the managed code does an explicit null check: url when though
column11: we hit this code: url  which doesn\'t check for
column12: and calls with it. This causes to access an invalid address and therefore we get a segmentation fault. The previous implementation was explicitly checking for in this case: url @marek-safar is okay with adding it back.  Why doesn\'t it crash with the JIT though? Because implicit null checking. Since the segmentation fault happens in managed code
column13: the crash handler assumes it must be a and thus throws such. We don\'t have such mechanism in place for the interpreter. Hard crashing isn\'t nice though
column14: so we should do something similar (although it shouldn\'t throw a imho
column15: but that is a separate issue)."'

column10: b'b" @lewurm @BrzVlad this should be revisited following the discussion on url  We should probably have an explicit null check for
column11: even if it won\'t protect us against other invalid addresses (like for example). In the longer term
column12: we should otherwise firgure out a way to
column13: in the SIGSEGV handler
column14: check if we are currently executing a managed method in the interpreter and act accordingly. "'

column10: b"b' This was fixed by url '"
b"b' Memory leak in file operations in mono 5.10'"
b'b" ## Steps to Reproduce  1. Seems to be related to using a lot of FileInfos  deleting
column11: copying
column12: appending files. I also access LastWriteTimeUtc alot which I suspect most apps don\'t. Essentially I have approximately 20 ffmpeg processes creating files 5 or so files (per process) every second in a tmpfs mount. I believe the relevant code is below.  Depending on the type of file the file extension in the search may be different but otherwise it\'s doing the same thing.  Finding files older than a certain time and either deleting them outright or combining them into a larger file on another drive and then deleting them.   Some files are copied to another drive and all deleted from tmpfs using the FileInfo Delete method The actual file  are done by opening a FileStream on another drive and writing bytes to it.  I could build an app to reproduce the issue if necessary.  I\'ve been putting out fires everywhere as it\'s been crashing my systems (my bad letting yum and apt auto-update systems).  My work around for now is to rollback mono on Centos 6 systems and use .net core on Centos 7 or Ubuntu systems.  ## Current Behavior As of Mono 5.10 I have an application that leaks memory very fast.  It can be using upwards of 80% of system memory according to top after running for a few hours.  The same app on the first version of mono 5.8 or older or on .net core holds steady at 1-3% of memory depending on the system (hundreds of installs).  ## Expected Behavior Memory usage holds steady instead of constantly increasing over time.  [ ] macOS [ X] Linux
column13: Centos 6
column14: Centos 7
column15: Ubuntu 16.04 [ ] Windows  **Version Used**: Works on mono 4.6.2
column18: 5.8.0.108 (unsure about the latest version of 5.8)
column19: doesn\'t work on mono 5.10.0.140 or 5.10.0.160  I\'m currently testing to see if mono  5.8.0.127 is affected.  ### Stacktrace "'

column10: b'b" This is a simple app to reproduce issue.  All this does is create small files
column11: find them
column12: and delete them.  **Use a tmpfs mount so it goes faster and you don\'t wreck your .** mkdir / mount -t tmpfs -o defaults
column13: size=64m
column14: noatime tmpfs / mono  /  This zip file has a Visual studio project file
column15: the single source file
column16: and a release build binary from VS 2017.  By all means build it yourself.  I didn\'t try building it with mono but I assume that doesn\'t matter as it only happens on mono 5.10 []url Leaks memory pretty fast on mono 5.10.0.160.  By the time the loop counter has hit a few thousand it\'s already doubled it\'s memory usage. By loop 6000 it\'s tripled.  Very easy to see after a few minutes.  Same test on mono 5.8.0.107 maintains steady memory usage the whole time.  As I mentioned earlier in the ticket
column17: earlier versions of mono such as 4.6.2
column19: 5.4 all work with constant memory usage.  The same code compiled as a .net core app and run under dotnet 2.0.6 also works fine.  This code is included in the zip file.  "'

b'b" @jaykrell I disagree
column11: it breaks a big assumption that matters: when passing an incorrect argument
column12: it would previously break
column13: and now it would just silently succeed. This is the same kind of problem where you print a warning instead of an assertion: it\'s most likely you are just going to ignore the error
column14: and even more importantly
column15: it might mask a  bug. A not-so-old case that we hit in Mono: we would previously silently ignore any error returned from any call
column16: and when canging to not silently ignore these errors anymore
column17: we discovered a whole set of bugs which we wouldn\'t previously hit (use-after-destroy
column18: non-initialized
column19: etc.).  Keeping the conditions of execution tight greatly help us in reasoning about the code
column20: and what possible cases are possible. Your change break these assumptions and just make the code harder to follow in general."'

column10: b"b' I agree warnings are ignored and useless. I would not warn here. I agree as well invalid parameters should be detected and fixed
column11: and errors not ignored. This case is like free(NULL). That is the precedent. NULL is not an invalid parameter to free. Like 0 is not an invalid parameter to add. '"

column10: b'b" @lambdageek\'s assertion here: url  is what this PR specifically does."'
b'b" NULL ignoring  is a common pattern in C. It does help a lot dealing with optional data. We gain nothing by forcing callees to check for those.  Worse than that
column11: probably a lot of the callees are missing NULL checks because we never ran into the error condition that triggers it.  I don\'t think the comparison between pthread_* return values and ignoring NULLs is fair. In the former
column12: we\'re in an unknown state
column13: while the later we\'re just handling one valid form of input. "'

b"b' Loading denied assemblies via can cause issues
column11: eg. for VSMac'"

column10: b'b\' Usually
column11: if an assembly depends on a known "bad"(windows specific implementation) assembly then the mono runtime can deny loading it. But if the load is initiated explicitly like via
column12: then the assembly gets loaded url  with a  .  For example
column13: take  . It\\\'s API\\\'s response depends on what platform it was built was for. So
column14: a windows specific version would return true even it is running on macOS. Normally
column15: this gets caught and denied loading. But if it is explicitly loaded via
column16: then that will break any subsequent code that depends on that API!  This can show up in VSMac
column17: if some addin loads the bad assembly before the good copy has been loaded into the app domain. Then the subsequent use of msbuild APIs that depend on break:   Here the windows specific code path runs on macOS
column18: because of the  \\\'s result!  Related: url \''

column10: b"b' @lambdageek @kumpera @marek-safar @mhutch @akoeplinger '"
b"b' Nice find!'"
b"b' @lambdageek did your context load changes fix the problem?'"

b'b\' @marek-safar No: the load context work did nothing about "problematic images" that\\\'s an entirely orthogonal concept.  The load context work changes the semantics of so that it is now subject to binding redirection via  or policy config files
column11: but I don\\\'t think that would help here our has the same version and public key token as the .NET Framework one binding redirection wouldn\\\'t help.  - What\\\'s not clear to me is what should do if you try to open a problematic image?  The simple answer is: fail in that case we can just drop the  and only keep the case:  url But that will break all callers of like whatever Monodevelop is doing in the bug that @radical mentioned.  A better answer might be "  should silently redirect to find our preferred version of the problematic image".  That\\\'s... doable but messy (because the loader is a mess) I wouldn\\\'t want to backport that to an imminent release.  So let me know what it should do.\''

column10: b'b\' Rewinding and adding full context :)  NuGet packagers assume that ".net framework" means "windows"
column11: so folks end up with windows-specific assemblies (often transitive dependencies) copied into their output folder without even realizing it
column12: which then breaks on Windows. This is an issue with several very common system.* packages
column13: so we have the Load deny mechanism for these specifically.  The problem in this case is that VSMac uses LoadFrom to load extensions\\\' assemblies
column14: and the deny mechanism only works with Load
column15: not LoadFrom.  I think silently redirecting LoadFrom to load the good variant when an image is denied is entirely reasonable and consistent. This isn\\\'t totally general
column16: so scope is limited. It\\\'s just swapping out specific known bad assemblies for good replacements that are bundled with Mono.  One could argue that the extensions shouldn\\\'t be shipping these assemblies. For the assemblies that are included in MD core that\\\'s definitely true
column17: and perhaps VSMac could add special handling to avoid loading them from extensions. However
column18: for assemblies that are not bundled in MD core
column19: the extension needs to bundle them to work on .NET Framework.  I understand the concern about backporting the patch. As a stopgap
column20: we could implement the same blocklist in  so MD doesn\\\'t get broken by extensions. We\\\'ve seen this breakage in the wild with the stable 7.5 release. /cc @slluis.\''

column10: b'b" @lambdageek I certainly prefer consistent behaviour in this case and we should use same logic as we do when loading the assembly using other API. That leaves use with only reflection context APIs behaving differently but that sounds reasonable to me.  I\'d like to see this in 2018-04 because we are still testing the release and we can take it out if necessary. I agree that backporting to earlier versions (15.8 and before) might be problematic but we\'d have to find a different workaround in that case."'
b"b' @lambdageek how confident are you to landing this to 2018-02?'"
b'b" @marek-safar I think it\'s probably worth backporting. It\'s not too disruptive. #8845 "'
b'b" We had to revert the fix for this issue on and  .  It\'s fixed on master (need at least 60f06e6ca26c28f874f67503cb58e7fb76095713 to both fix this issue and also not break MSBuild)."'
b"b' @lambageek is that a temporary revert or do we need to think about alternative workarounds for MD running on those releases?  /cc @slluis'"

b'b" @mhutch The main motivation for the reverts was to unblock XI and XA moving to 2018-04 and to re-enable nightly CI builds of the MDK.  The corrected fix for 2018-06 is in PR #9170. ~I\'m going to do the 2018-04 updated PR imminently.~ The corrected 2018-04 fix is in #9171 "'

column10: b'b" ## Steps to Reproduce  The reproduction case is just to compile an  app on macOS. However
column11: not all apps seem to be affected. I have uncovered two Xamarin client applications that are affected

column10: b'b\' \\xe2\\x80\\xa6emaphore (#6222)"  This reverts commit 5f5c5e97a08f7086d7c18af37352c4a03dc4c0d1.  While that change simplifies the code
column11: it caused regression. In particular
column12: it appears there is no longer coordination between shutdown and the threadpool
column13: leading to hangs at shutdown
column14: of a bounded random but significant duration. i.e. because threadpool workers do a random wait
column15: and then check for shutdown in progress. Previously the wait was interrupted.  The hang is often long enough to cause  to fail CI. The hang is usually very obvious running
column16: even if it is within the threshold allowed by CI. The hang is long enough to make building mono many times slower on . I\\\'m guessing due to different random number generation? I\\\'m guessing this is the same issue. But the problems with  are severe enough.\''

column10: b"b' What is the root cause of this bug? Did you understood exactly how it is supposed to work
column11: and how the assumptions are broken and trigger this regression? You are trying to revert the symptom without figuring out the root of the problem.'"

column10: b"b' Yes. I indicated so. I believe previously shutdown would interrupt the waits
column11: now it does not. So now the random wait times out.'"

column10: b"b' For the Skylake architecture and above Intel decided to change the instruction from 10 cycles to 140 cycles.  This causes upto a x14 degradation in type spinning (contended
column12: use of
column13: etc)  See issue in url  Also CoreClr fix in url The TechEmpower hardware in the physical scenerios uses Skylake architecture
column14: so it would be good to eliminate this as an difference (also is good to fix for people on Skylake and above)  /cc @migueldeicaza '"

column11: so I fail to see where we\'d need that."'

column10: b'b" we don\'t do spinning using in the runtime."'

column11: we don\'t plan on having the sort of aggressive spinning that coreclr does as it comes at the expense of power usage which we care more than the extra few % of perf in some workloads. "'

column10: b"b' From the coreclr issue Though it looks like translates to (1 cycle) rather than (10 cycles Using is still a tight loop burning CPU
column11: where as releases all CPU resource to the second thread under hyperthreading or moves the CPU to a low power state.  From [Benefitting Power and Performance Sleep Loops Intel]url > The pause  instruction can be used in conjunction with a Sleep(0) to construct something similar to an exponential back-off in situations where the lock or more work may become available in a short period of time
column12: and the performance may benefit from a short spin in ring 3. '"

column10: b"b' And depending how much framework or coreclr code is consumed:  ![image]url  From [Why Skylake CPUs Are Sometimes 50% Slower \\xe2\\x80\\x93 How Intel Has Broken Existing Code]url  '"
b"b' Fair enough. We should add support for PAUSE / YIELD and tune those BCL knobs to be geared towards low power.'"
b'b" Since we\'re here. We should audit usage of  and . BCL code should have a very good reason to use former (including caching its value) and not the later."'

b'b" BCL code should have a very good reason to use former (including caching its value) and not the later.  I believe the caching is because checking the cpu count is an expensive synchronising request; and cpus counts don\'t change that frequently? (so it only rechecks every N requests)  The risk of not caching is it becomes expensive; so users then manually cache it in a ending up with a fixed value rather than one which at least updates?"'
b'b" @benaadams \\xe2\\x9d\\xa4\\xef\\xb8\\x8f  I could not explain why after a server / cpu change from Ivy to Skylake mono performance has dropped now it\'s clear!"'
b"b' Doesn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t spinning save battery as often as it is faster on non-battery? I mean
column11: I understand it is all heuristic and that spinning is worse under contention.  In either case
column12: ideally
column13: this belongs at the next layer down
column14: in usermode and not in the kernel
column15: and on Linux we probably already get that
column16: possibly all systems.  i.e. Linux kernel only has futex and pthreads probably only uses that after a spin. All the pthread systems are probably similar in this regard.  Win32 SRWLock
column17: CondVar
column18: CritSec all spin. They are all usermode constructs.  Win32 Event
column19: Mutex
column20: Semaphore is what you want to avoid using directly
column21: for performance
column22: unless you have highly contended locks
column25: all of which should be rare. They are kernel constructs.'"

b'b\' watchOS: "fastcc" not supported with Xcode 10\\\'s clang\''
b'b\' Repro:  * Download Xcode 10 beta 2
column11: and configure Visual Studio for Mac to use it. Restart Visual Studio for Mac. * Create a new iOS app and add a watchOS extension (or download & open []url  * Change to a Release|Device configuration and build. * Install  from the xcode10 branch either built from source or a package from CI
column12: which are available as GitHub statuses here: url  (I\\\'m not sure this is required
column13: believe this bug should reproduce with any version of
column14: but I haven\\\'t tested it)  Result: Complete build log: url I opened a radar with Apple about this
column15: and they said:  This issue behaves as intended based on the following:  The Mono developers decided to use "fastcc". This has never been a supported configuration but happened to "work" before clang-1000 because Clang is compiled with assertions turned off. The check was turned into a true error on clang-1000
column16: leading to this failure.  So we need to stop using fastcc.  This is a blocker for our Xcode 10 support
column17: since it breaks our watchOS story completely.\''

column10: b"b' @vargaz could you please take a look at that? Thank you.'"
b"b' @spouliot what is the dev releases alignment for our xcode 10 support?'"
b'b" Where is the error message about using \'fastcc\' ? We are using preserveall_cc
column11: we can get rid of that if needed."'

column10: b'b" preserve_allcc is a calling convention saving all registers
column11: we use it around calls to init functions so they don\'t clobber argument registers. Disabling it is going to make the code
column12: but it will still work."'

column11: and __thread with Win32/gcc

column10: b"b' instead of much slower TlsGetValue / TlsSetValue.'"
b'b" Wierd all around. I didn\'t close it. The errors don\'t make sense. I pushed an update with  no change due to  the nonsense errors."'
b"b' This is meant to be an empty PR? Sure
column11: go for it. Just make sure to fully understand all issues documented in mono-tls.c become committing to it. '"

column10: b'b\' The "real" PR  failed to compile  in wierd says so I\\\'m baselining an empty PR first. Building locally with  worked
column11: and the PR failed with msvc.  The main "problems" with  __declspec(thread):  1. Don\\\'t work often pre-Vista -only in the  .exe and static dependents of it.  2. Different cross-dll semantics. I.e. tls keys can be passed across dlls and lifetime not tied to a dll. __declspec(thread) lifetime is tied to a .dll. I\\\'ve seen that bite one project. Usually people tie TLS keys to .dlls anyway.  3. They aren\\\'t fiber local. A different and contradictory change that I would reluctantly agree with is to  use FlsAlloc instead. __declspec(fiber) would be ideal
column12: but it doesn\\\'t exist. We do actually sometimes  use FlsAlloc
column13: but only sometimes. The inconsistency seems bad.   We do have other uses of TlsAlloc that should probably be __declspec(thread) but I left them alone for now.\''

b"b'  or Timezone information do not transition out of DST for all time zones'"

b'b\' ### Note Using Vatican time zone as an example. ## Steps to Reproduce  1. Turn off NTP time synchronization for linux2. Turn off any other network time synchronization services that may be active 3. Set the time zone on the server to the Vatican time zone4. Set the time of the OS to 1 hour and 1 minute before the reported DST Exit datetime of 10/28/2018 3:### Current Behavior  The mono application will not transition out of DST for two hours past DST exit. #### OS Linux Run Output #### Mono application run: #### Before transition  #### After transition  #### The current time is still reporting that we are in DST. 3AM instead of 2AM The print "Not in DST" is from the application calculating that we have exited DST based on the ticks of the system. #### If the application is allowed to run for another hour
column11: mono will partially transition.  #### The UTC+Offset calculation will be correct
column12: but the  will still return the incorrect information.   #### Waiting one more hour
column13: the mono application\\\'s  will be in sync with the system time  ### Platforms  Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS  ### Mono application\\\'s code  \''

b'b" I have another report of this issue. IN this case it caused a serious problem with an app. This past March 9
column11: in CST
column12: the customer\'s app
column13: which is using  for times
column14: jumped from 7:59 PM to 9:00 PK
column15: seemingly going to CDT (Central Daylight Time) 6 hours early. Doing some more testing I found the following (did not test all time zones):  **In Central ST
column16: time jumped from 3/9 7:59 PM to 9:00 PM. So between 3/9 8:00 PM CST and 3/10 2:00 AM CST
column17: shows 1 hour ahead of actual.** In Eastern ST
column18: as expected.  In Mountain ST
column19: as expected  In Pacific ST
column20: as expected  **in Alaska ST
column21: time jumped from 3/9 4:59 PM to 6:00 PM So between 3/9 5:00 PM AST and 3/10 2:00 AM AST
column22: shows 1 hour ahead of actual.** Atlantic ST as expected  **Azores ST (Portugal)
column23: time jumps from 3/30 10:59 PM to 3/31 12:00 AM. So between 3/30 11:00 PM Azores ST and 3/31 12:00 AM Azores ST
column24: shows 1 hour ahead of actual.** Those are all I tested so far  ## To reproduce:  1. Create a Mono Console app and write  to the console 2. Set your system time to Central Standard time March 9 at 9 PM. 3. Run the console app  Expected result: Time printed to console should match the system time in the Mac menu bar (or system time of the linux computer)  Actual result: Time printed to console is 1 hour ahead of the system time  ## Mono version: Mono 5.16.0.238 (2018-06/99d74f7f6ee) (64-bit) Package version: 516000238  "'

column10: b"b' For the 5 affected time zones noted in my comments above
column11: in Mono 5.18.1.18
column12: DST for those 5 areas are no longer starting DST early. But now they are all starting DST 1 hour late. I.e if the time is supposed to jump from 2:00 AM to 3:00 AM
column13: instead it is jumping from 3:00 AM to 4:00 AM. breakdown:  Central Standard time (US)
column14: Eastern ST (Turks and Caicos)
column15: and Alaska Standard Time: Should jump from 2:00 AM to 3:00 AM but  jumps from 3:00 AM to 4:00 AM  Cuba Standard Time and  Azores Standard Time: Should jump from 12:00 AM to 1:00 AM but  jumps from 1:00 AM to 2:00 AM  I only tested in a non-affected area for EST New York. This worked correctly. I did not test for any other locations where the issue was not occurring as per my notes in my previous comments'"

column10: b"b' @alexischr please have a look'"
b"b' I am not 100% sure from one crash but:  The crash appears to be happening on shutdown
column11: where the runtime starts to install interrupt handlers to force-abort all Mono threads that are in unmanaged blocking code. The CFRunLoop thread
column12: (the messsage loop thread used for the filesystem events) already has an interrupt handler installed
column13: and only one  can be installed per thread.  Possible approaches: * use and protect the loop from interrupting until it uninstalls its interrupt. The thread is set as background
column14: so blocking may not stop it from getting aborted * Have the runtime use the existing interrupt. I think it already does most of the time; this crash has not been reproduced on Mono or VSfM. This situation may happen if the first interrupt takes too long * Uninstall the old interrupt handler before trying to install the new one '"

column10: b"b' Please reopen if you can still reproduce it with newer versions'"

column10: b"b' Serialization error in nightly build'"

b'b" ## Steps to Reproduce This was found attempting to get the C# semantic tests running on Mono  1. Clone url  1. Check out the branch 1. Make sure mono is on your path 1. Run 1. Run   ### Actual Behavior This will run the Symbol unit tests only and eventually Mono will throw an exception trying to call across instances. The error is a during serialization ### Expected Behavior The xunit process runs to completion ## On which platforms did you notice this  This was discovered on Ubuntu 18.04. I\'m using the latest nightly mono as described by the Download page  url  ## Stacktrace and full details  "'
b"b' Note: this appears to be a regression between the stable and nightly Mono feeds. These tests all run fine in stable but fail as soon as I move to nightly.'"
b"b' @kg could you look into this one'"
b"b' Started looking at it earlier
column11: will try to come up with a fix'"

column10: b'b" I spent most of the week on this and am completely stumped: * BinaryFormatter is failing to serialize a dict* It fails for different string values * It is almost 100% reproducible but not 100% * Threading is not required for it to fail
column11: and there is a lock around the only bits of shared state it uses (the formatter and its surrogate selector) * Replicating all the relevant logic in a reduced test case either by hand or via remoting does not reproduce the issue * The code responsible for serializing the data is pretty simple. I\'ve ruled out every failure theory I can come up with * Deserializing the bundle immediately after serializing it (in the same domain) fails
column12: just like in the destination domain
column13: so it isn\'t a problem specific to crossing domains * The bad bundle fails to deserialize on windows .net framework with the same* error as it does for us My only guess is that this is some sort of corruption issue related to the fact that the strings are coming directly out of reflection metadata (to be specific
column14: custom attributes that specify traits for xunit test cases). But the strings look totally valid
column15: and we\'re not getting any sort of heap corruption crashes or garbage data when examining the managed objects... The trait data looks correct
column16: also.  We haven\'t touched any of the involved formatter code in ages as far as I can tell
column17: so if we broke this it\'s somehow broken by changes in some related system. I\'ll try to bisect it but it\'s tricky since the process of building and running the tests is 15-30 minutes per go."'

Something about these equality mismatches is thoroughly breaking the reflection or serialization infrastructure so it never works right again."'

column11: if you use latest mono those hangs should be gone now. I suspect we may have regressed some other cmod related tests
column12: though I did not see any failures when I ran the test suite locally.'"

column10: b'b" # Possible workarounds (so far)  You can choose one of the following known workarounds:  ## 1. Install mono 5.16 from scratch _(Update: Do not use this workaround
column11: instead workaround 2 is recommended.)_ Remove mono completely and reinstall the latest version (i.e. 5.16). This is an easy workaround
column12: but takes some time. Also you may have to install mono dependent packages again. **Only choose this solution
column13: if this is not a problem.** To me it is still unclear
column14: why this solves the problem. _(Update: It\'s clear now
column15: the install scripts will run the AOT compilation of mscorlib before the mono-llvm-support package is being unpacked. Therefore the LLVM AOT bug is not in action. When upgrading mono 5.14 to 5.16 the AOT compilation happens after the mono-llvm-support package is being unpacked ## 2. Remove llvm support Run as root:  ## 3. Disable AOT compilation You can disable AOT compilation via an environment variable  . It should be possible to do this globally in  . This might affect the performance of your applications. "'

column10: b"b' So
column11: here is another update...  @lewurm First of all the mono-llvm-support package for armhf is there since mono 5.14. (Checking the packages at url ### Installing mono 5.16 from scratch (no exception)  Install 5.16 log   Note
column12: that the AOT compilation of mscorlib happens **before** the mono-llvm-support package is being unpacked. (imo the wrong order) That basically means that LLVM is not used when installing mono 5.16 from scratch. Therefore the example is not throwing an exception.  ### Upgrading mono 5.14 to 5.16 (exception)  Install 5.14 log  Upgrade to 5.16 log   When upgrading to mono 5.16 the mono-llvm-support package is being unpacked **before** the AOT compilation of mscorlib happens. (imo the right order) This explains why the upgraded 5.16. version throws an exception with the example program.  ## Conclusion  ### 1. LLVM AOT Bug As @lewurm pointed out there is a bug in the LLVM enabled AOT compilation of the mscorlib. The bug was introduced in 5.16
column13: because I checked the 5.14 version with manually running AOT compilation of mscorlib again and there happens no exception in the example program. Hence the bug was introduced after 5.14. Should we create a new issue for investigating the LLVM AOT bug? Who can help?  ### 2. Debian packages  scripts issue There is a problem when installing mono from scratch
column14: because the mono-llvm-support package is being unpacked after the AOT compilation of mscorlib has happened. When upgrading an existing mono install
column15: the order is the other way around. Imo the right order is to unpack the mono-llvm-support package first and then do the mscorlib AOT compilation. Also install and upgrade scripts should be consistent regarding the order of the two dependent steps. Who can help? (@directhex ?)  Should we create a new issue for this matter?'"

b"b' Add the module filename to any stack frames in the crash report'"
b"b' We need to add the module filename to any stack frames in the crash report.  Currently
column11: we only place the MVID (module version id) as the identifier in crash reports
column12: which means if we cannot resolve the MVID then we have no information about the frame at all (see \\xe2\\x80\\xa6the second frame is not resolved).  Here\\xe2\\x80\\x99s the raw form from the un-symbolized report:   We must have the module name here to ensure the crash report is trendable between versions.  For example
column13: let\\xe2\\x80\\x99s say that the attached issue is caused by .  This module will have a different MVID if it has been updated between versions.  This means that when we ship two versions of Visual Studio for Mac with the same issue in it
column14: we will create two different failure buckets\\xe2\\x80\\xa6causing us to not count hits of this issue correctly (and potentially miss a high impact issue because it was spread to multiple failures).  /cc @leculver'"

timestamp": 0x87654321   },  We don\\\'t need the full filepath (so not "/"), just the module name (") so that we know where the frame came from in case we can\\\'t symbolize the result.  We should still leave in the guid, since other tools use it now.\''

column11: and the standard symbol server indexing process uses the Optional Header \\xe2\\x80\\x9cSizeOfImage\\xe2\\x80\\x9d field and the IMAGE_FILE_HEADER \\xe2\\x80\\x9cTimeDateStamp\\xe2\\x80\\x9d field.  By having the filename
column12: SizeOfImage
column13: and TimeDateStamp we can pull archived binaries from the symbol server instead of having to download the entire mono or VS for Mac packages to resolve symbols.  /cc @leculver'"

column12: emulation of SSE4.1. Can\'t very well expect people to install external tools just to continue using the one that broke in the first place. That\'s just messy. Emulating it is probably slower than not using it at all. OK

b'b" [android][armv7][aot][llvm] Llvm generates invalid code because datalayout isn\'t set"'
b'b" This bug is a continuation of a  issue at url  A lot of details has been added there
column11: but I\'ll try to list the important parts here as well.  Creating a new  app in VS with the latest  master (or d16-0 p2 branch) causes a crash on code generated by llvm.  Some infos :  Crash only occurs on AOT+LLVM on armeabi-v7a architecture. It doesn\'t matter if it runs on a armv7 or arm64 device
column12: since the issue is in the generated code. The  issue provides a disassembly of the offending function
column13: plus disassembly of the bitcode before and after opt is run. The problem occurs when running opt. On armeabi-v7a
column14: this is what happens :  Before   After   The optimisation for getelementptr changed from 3 * to 6 *
column15: which is clearly wrong on armeabi-v7a. I managed to have it fixed by passing   to opt to set the data layout for llvm url  Otherwise
column16: it looks like llvm will otherwise do suppositions when running opt and was supposing that we have 64-bit pointers. From what I could find in the Mono source
column17: it recently started setting the data layout and target triple
column18: but only for wasm. From the llvm reference
column19: Therefore
column20: from what I understand of it
column21: Mono should always be specifying a target data (or
column23: when cross-compiling) otherwise opt is within its right to suppose and optimise the code based on what it thinks is the target data layout.  ## Steps to Reproduce  1. Create a new  Single-View App in VS on Windows. 2. Disable Shared Runtime
column24: Activate AOT+LLVM and build only for armeabi-v7a 3. Build and run (armeabi-v7a or arm64-v8a device
column26: as long as only armv7 is built) 4. Notice the crash  ### Current Behavior  App crashes  ### Expected Behavior  App actually runs  ## On which platforms did you notice this  [ ] macOS [ ] Linux [x] Windows  **Version Used**: master 9.1.199.72 This uses mono at commit 23f2024af80776b4bb9d44ca1369d0c5bace3914

column10: b'b" Based on url  I can find this section and  >Instead
column11: if specified
column12: the target data layout is required to match what the ultimate code generator expects. This string is used by the mid-level optimizers to improve code
column13: and this only works if it matches what the ultimate code generator uses. There is no way to generate IR that does not embed this target-specific detail into the IR. **If you don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t specify the string
column14: the default specifications will be used to generate a Data Layout and the optimization phases will operate accordingly and introduce target specificity into the IR with respect to these default specifications**.  From what I can figure out
column15: the documentation is pretty much saying that we should always be setting a datalayout
column16: because otherwise opt would not really be able to do its job properly (my guess is not being to optimize anything related to a pointer because you don\'t know its size would make optimisations pretty much useless). However
column17: finding this info
column18: I\'m worried that the issue would happen as well on x86 for Android. I think I have an old x86 Android device hanging around somewhere
column19: I\'ll try and repro it on this."'

column10: b"b' Added a layout for x86 as well. '"
b'b" Just an FYI
column11: I couldn\'t find that old x86 Android device
column12: so sadly I can\'t confirm the issue there."'

b'b" Currently  is included in the mono repository. Is it worth splitting it out into it\'s own repository and creating a nuget package from it.  I was recently working on a project on Windows that uses . I was getting compile errors because of a missing method. After investigating a bit I noticed that the version of  that is included with the gtk-sharp msi installer for Windows included an older version of . This got me thinking that it\'d be nice to have it split out and publish the assembly on nuget so that we could easily have a consistent version across all platforms and not have it tied to the mono repository.  Thoughts?"'
b"b' /cc @akoeplinger @Therzok @bratsche @directhex thoughts?  Maybe also things like  specifically things like  ?'"

b'b\' We usually do it only for code where we see a potential for future improvements and development. If the nuget packaging is the only "addition" to what we have today I\\\'d much prefer to allow building the package from Mono than moving code around\''

column11: we can keep the code here
column12: and just add the NuPkg files to do the build.  Additionally

column14: but it brings the burden on Mono to bring another submodule.'"

column10: b"b' [2018-08] [runtime] Fix building older runtimes with newer system Mono'"
b'b\' What was happening was that this was building with a  from the build profile
column11: but was trying to load the system .  Those versions mismatch when building 2018-08 with a nightly mono that is 5.23.0.  Rather than messing with the MONO_PATH and risking shadowing something important there
column12: I chose to copy the  files into this "" directory that we are using for the emitted executable. It is loaded by the system Mono as the correct  to use
column13: as assemblies in the same folder have precedence.  This fixes the build. Backport of #12573. /cc @alexanderkyte \''

b"b' On armv7 our calling convention happens to be the same as the platform one. However
column11: when using a armv7 cross compiler to generate bitcode that targets a different platform (e.g. arm64_32) the calling convention can be different (e.g. on arm64_32
column12: a return buffer must be passed via r8). Thus
column13: mark it properly for LLVM so it can generate correct code. Backport of #12894. /cc @lewurm '"

column10: b"b' Internal obsolete constructor and Mono-specific cancellation behavior.'"

b'b" Edit (Martin): Let\'s use this issue to consolidate and track all the status of this issue. I will keep this updated with the current status.  - Looks like we probably changed StreamContent around and as a result the .ctor this code needs is missing?   url "'
b"b' /cc @baulig could you investigate'"
b"b' See my comment in url '"
b'b" @baulig we need to bring it back as it\'s breaking things"'

b'b" We also need to carefully distinguish between the _constructor_ and the _behavior_ (*) here.  Bringing back the constructor alone is unacceptable it\'s either a trivial fix for them to change their code or they\'re relying on the _behavior_; in which case we\'d artificially cause trouble and make people waste their time by hiding a problem.  So the only thing that really makes sense is to bring back the old _behavior_ (which would obviously include that constructor).  However
column11: before doing so
column12: I would like to understand where this is used
column13: how it is used and why this cancellation is needed.  Long-term
column14: our goal should be not to rely on internal Mono APIs or Mono-specific behavior
column15: and I would like to take this as an opportunity to either fix the relevant code in MonoDevelop or discuss this behavior with the CoreFX team and possibly upstream it.  We can do a quick temporary hot-fix with an to unblock people
column16: though.  (*) The behavior is the assumption that you can cancel by using that internal constructor but is
column17: so it\'s called by some internal code."'

column10: b"b' PR for a _temporary_ hot-fix is up: url Please keep this issue open even after that PR is merged
column11: so we can discuss and work towards a more permanent solution.'"
