column10: b'b" I can\'t reproduce any leaks by calling that pinvoke in a loop (tried both on arm board and desktop ubuntu). Maybe there is missing code that was producing the leak
column11: since the original sample is not building from the start.  Also
column12: you might want to check the memory consumption of the mono process
column13: not the total free memory available on the system"'

column10: b"b' I have created setup on ARM target where when bare Linux is running there is no change in memory consumption. Now I have run an application which is calling Unmanaged function. I observed memory of that process it is continuously decreasing. I wait till it reaches to lowest memory figure
column11: I found once it reaches near to 2-3 MB figure it has reclaim some amount of memory (In My case I found nearly 50 MB). Now I am not sure it is Leak or Behaviour of GC to handle memory.  Is there any way I can set Limit to GC about reclaim memory?  I also not get why it has to reclaim only a certain amount? Please correct me If I am in wrong in handling or calling an unmanaged function.  I have attached code with .NET solution & eclipse library project so it will be easy to use.  []url  '"

column10: b'b" I\'m still not reproducing any weird memory behavior and I don\'t understand what exactly is the problem that you are encountering. You say you have a leak
column11: but the memory used by the process is reclaimed and decreasing ? Please pass MONO_LOG_LEVEL=debug and MONO_LOG_MASK=gc environment variables to the mono process and attach the output here.  By default the size of the minor generation is 4MB (nursery-size). We do a minor gc when it gets filled and alive objects are promoted to major heap. When the major heap first reaches 4 * nursery-size (this limit might be constant to 16MB on 5.8.0)
column12: we do the fist major. You can control the nursery-size using MONO_GC_PARAMS=nursery-size=..M)"'

b"b' Memory leak using Google Calendar API'"

b'b" []url Using Google Calendar C# API on Linux causes significant memory leak. Must be Mono issue because on Windows it\'s running ok. Could be related to url  but it\'s closed?  ## Steps to Reproduce  1. Obtain google calendar api credentials url  2. Execute attached solution (it expects ClentID and ClientSecret command line arguments) 3. Memory usage steadily grows after each API request ### Current Behavior  Memory usage grows after each API request (appr. by 1Mb) After running for a day (at 15 sec intervals) memory usage goes to 1 Gb  ### Expected Behavior  Stable memory usage. On Windows it\'s using 20~30 Mb  ## On which platforms did you notice this  [ ] macOS [x] Linux Ubuntu 18.10 (VM) [ ] Windows  **Version Used**:  5.20.1.19  "'
b'b" Hi
column11: I think what you might be seeing is a property of how Mono\'s garbage collector (sgen) behaves.  By default sgen will ask the OS for more memory whenever it needs to grow the major heap.  you can run the program with some debugging output from sgen by setting  .  You can also limit the maximum size of the major heap by setting (for a small 50mb heap not realistic for real programs but good enough for this example).  One other thing that I did
column12: was to add a call to inside the loop body after to trigger a major collection after each loop iteration.  With this change and with the above environment variables set
column13: I get into a steady state:   So mono is using about 24mb for its major heap and about 114k for its large object space."'

For production I had to extract Google Calendar API code into separate service and use .NET Remoting to communicate with it.  So now when I detect that the service memory usage goes above configurable threshold (i.e. 500Mb) the service will just kill itself.  And when client needs it the service will restart. column11: this is not really a bug I\'d rather say HttpClient is behaving as expected.  What is happening is that the file you\'re attempting to download is 2167849215 bytes in size that\'s slightly over 2 GB.  While is a
column12: it won\'t allow you to set it to anything larger than (which is  ).  It also won\'t make any sense to increase that limit because allocating over 2 GB of memory isn\'t really such a good idea.  When you pass
column13: then it will only read the headers and not buffer the entire response body (like it does when using the default of  )."'

b'b\'  And this is where we disagree. The HTTP client should *never* allocate any more (no matter what the request type is) memory than it needs to transfer the resource from the server to the local system. And by "transfer" I don\\\'t mean storing in memory
column11: but doing the right thing to get the *entire* resource from there to here. Nowhere the process requires allocating more than a few KB of memory to transfer the data (I usually use 8-16K) chunks from the server. Then what happens to the chunks depends on the expected size of the resource. There are three strategies here to consider:  1. Don\\\'t download all the data right away
column12: let the HttpClient user get it at their own pace they will know what to do with it. This means
column13: fill the buffer(s) from the network only when is called on the HttpClient data stream
column14: any size the calling party requests. 2. If the data is small (for an arbitrary definition of "small" either a predetermined number or a percentage of available free memory) then
column15: by all means
column16: use MemoryStream as a backing store 3. If the data is big
column17: use a temporary file stream to stash the data and have the HttpClient user load the data from there (i.e. the HttpClient content stream becomes a file stream)  There is **really** no need to allocate as much memory as the resource size indicates: this is an open gateway to DoS exploits.  And throwing an exception from a **library** because the size is too big and the library does the wrong thing is really bad let the calling party decide what to do by using one of the 3 above options on the library side. I understand your point
column18: but my stance hasn\\\'t changed :)\''

And you can then freely decide how you want to do that whether you store it in a temp file

column10: b'b" Short update
column11: after investigation I have pinpointed the problem for trusted certificate validation problem when using Mono and ). First there are a couple of things to be aware of when setting things up in order for it to work under boringssl using the default certificate store locations.  * Certificates must be imported into default machine  user store using certtools since that is the only version that support the new stores used by boringssl as well as supporting older legacy  providers.  * There is currently a bug in boringssl handling of X509_LOOKUP_add_dir. In openssl repro there are a couple of defines for path separator
column12: but looks like boringssl made this part Unix specific
column13: meaning that Windows paths won\'t work as expected. This needs to be patched in the boringssl version used by Mono in order to work (potentially in other places as well).  So in order for the default certificate store lookups to work on Windows platforms we will need to patch our boringssl implementation to support Windows style paths. "'

column10: b"b' Link with -z now or -bind_at_load.'"
b'b\' Advantages:  Dynamic linker gets out of the way of random function calls
column11: in terms of timing
column12: in terms of locking
column13: and in term of success
column14: and possibly in terms of security (readonly function pointers).  If you successfully load
column15: then you can make function calls with impunity
column16: without regard as to if they are in the same .so as the caller
column17: well
column18: assuming they are to a leaf like libc
column19: or to something itself built with -z now. The "success" is significant
column20: as otherwise loaded LLVM has unresolved symbols lurking
column21: depending on which code paths you send it down.  Disadvantage: Slower startup.  Mixed:  Platform consistency
column22: since this is how Windows behaves usually (unless you say link /delayload)  This will combine well with an upcoming revision of url Difficult alternative: Force the binding along sensitive paths by calling their callees earlier. Typical alternative: Ignore the matter. \''

b"b' Audit  entry points for blocking calls that need runtime GC transitions'"
b'b\' As mostly stated in url The CoreFX PAL library (  ) needs to be audited
column11: in a similar way as the runtime was audited in url  The sources lie mainly in url  and what\\\'s included on the Mono-built library is here: url Big parts of this library are used via  by the current Mono BCL (and all of it will be used with .NET 5 Mono).  The biggest "hint" for a blocking call in these functions is the motif. When such a call is found:  * The while loop needs to be broken up since we actually allow interrupting blocking calls: url * The  must be substituted with an icall bind + managed implementation of the broken up while loop (transitioning out of the icall processes the if its sourced by the runtime itself; if it\\\'s not sourced by the runtime
column12: the syscall does need to be retried): url * The icall must be implemented with the GC safety transitions: url For now
column13: we could start from the BCL code and find which functions from the PAL are actually being used currently. In the future it is expected that all of them will be used by Mono. \''

column10: b"b' The CoreFX PAL library is used via regular PInvokes. Regular PInvokes should be free to block as much as they want. It is how it works in CoreCLR
column11: on both Windows and Unix. Why is it not the case in Mono? Does that mean that PInvokes in 3rd party libraries have to avoid blocking as well?'"

column10: b"b' Since we want to use the corefx PAL as it is in .net core
column11: we need to do this some other way.  '"

column10: b'b" For netcore we use CoreFX differently than how we integrated . The CoreFX code comes as full implementation for us with no runtime dependencies. The native dependencies are used primary via pinvokes which cannot assume the native call will not block indefinitely. This is slower than icalls but probably not recognizable for platform calls
column11: we could introduce e.g. InternalPInvoke to CoreFX for calls which we know can have less safety but that\'s not the case today.  What is worth  are the internal calls for netcore mode as they all should be calling runtime only (not platform implementation) API but I think that\'s the case already. "'

b'b\' Fixes: url  Fixes: url The function generated by was overwriting a part of the previous stack frame because it was not creating a large enough new stack frame for itself. I used a local build of [1@87a80b][0] to verify that this change resolved both of the issues linked above.  I also confirmed that I was able to reintroduce the issues in my local environment by removing the change and rebuilding.  After this change
